passages.text: Beauty will be CONVULSIVE or will not be at all.
The imaginary is what tends to become real.
Surrealism is based on the belief in the superior reality of certain forms of previously neglected associations, in the omnipotence of dream, in the disinterested play of thought.
The mind which plunges into Surrealism relives with glowing excitement the best part of its childhood.
I believe in the future resolution of these two states, dream and reality, which are seemingly so contradictory, into a kind of absolute reality, a surreality.
The man who cannot visualize a horse galloping on a tomato is an idiot.
Perhaps I am doomed to retrace my steps under the illusion that I am exploring, doomed to try and learn what I should simply recognize.
Words make love.
It is living and ceasing to live that are imaginary solutions. Existence is elsewhere.
The simplest Surrealist act consists of dashing down into the street, pistol in hand, and firing blindly, as fast as you can pull the trigger, into the crowd.
passages.context: Provocative definition of pure act—not literal

passages.text: There is nothing with which it is so dangerous to take liberties as liberty itself.
Everything tends to make us believe that there exists a certain point of the mind at which life and death, the real and the imagined, past and future cease to be perceived as contradictions.
Let us not mince words: the marvelous is always beautiful, anything marvelous is beautiful, in fact only the marvelous is beautiful.
Beloved imagination, what I most like in you is your unsparing quality.
The eye exists in its savage state.
Psychic automatism in its pure state—the dictation of thought in the absence of all control exercised by reason.
We are still living under the reign of logic. But the methods of logic are applied nowadays only to the resolution of problems of secondary interest.
Language has been given to man so that he may make Surrealist use of it.
The mind of the man who dreams is fully satisfied by what happens to him.
What is admirable about the fantastic is that there is no longer anything fantastic: there is only the real.
